word.entryDescription: a long-lasting mark that is left after a damaged area of skin has healed
word.entryExample: I'm worried that it might leave a scar.

word.entryDescription: frightened or worried
word.entryExample: The room was dark and the boy was very scared.

word.entryDescription: a long item of clothing you wear around the neck
word.entryExample: I want to buy my mum a scarf for her birthday.

word.entryDescription: something that is scary makes you feel afraid
word.entryExample: This movie is scary!

word.entryDescription: a single part of a film, play, etc that happens in one place at one particular time
word.entryExample: The director said the actors needed to get ready for the next scene.

word.entryDescription: the background and objects used to represent a place in a play
word.entryExample: The children all helped to make the scenery for the school play.

word.entryDescription: an official plan or system
word.entryExample: It would be wrong to abandon the scheme now.

word.entryDescription: a place of education for children
word.entryExample: How do you travel to school?

word.entryDescription: a signal in a school that tells the students when it is time to go to class in the morning and when it is time to change classes during the day
word.entryExample: The school bell started to ring.

word.entryDescription: a meal, typically in the middle of the school day, provided to students at school
word.entryExample: School dinners are ok, but I'd really prefer to have take away fish and chips.

word.entryDescription: someone who has recently left school
word.entryExample: Only school leavers and graduates can apply for this job.

word.entryDescription: the study of the physical world
word.entryExample: He's an astronaut because he loves space and science.

word.entryDescription: films or books about imagined future worlds, people or events, often involving technologies that are not yet possible
word.entryExample: I really like a good science fiction film.

word.entryDescription: the usual process of finding out information in science; involves testing one's ideas by making experiments
word.entryExample: This way of working is called 'following the scientific method'.

word.entryDescription: somebody who works in or deals with science
word.entryExample: Scientists look at the world around them and think about questions they want to answer.

word.entryDescription: a child's vehicle with a tall handle and two wheels joined to a board. You stand on the board with one foot and push with the other foot to move forward.
word.entryExample: My little sister can ride a scooter.

word.entryDescription: the number of goals, points, etc that players, teams or students have in a game, competition or exam
word.entryExample: I haven't got my score yet, but I don't think it will be very good!

word.entryDescription: to gain a point, goal, etc in sport
word.entryExample: Harry scored the third goal of the match.

word.entryDescription: a small tropical animal like an insect with eight legs, two front claws, a curving tail and a poisonous sting
word.entryExample: Scorpions live in hot countries.

word.entryDescription: a flat area on a computer, television, etc on which words or pictures appear
word.entryExample: The screen on their tablet stays bright when used outdoors.

word.entryDescription: an object made by an artist out of stone, metal, wood, etc, or this particular form of art.
word.entryExample: Nathalie didn't like any of the sculptures.

word.entryDescription: a memory card used in portable devices, such as mobile phones, digital cameras, tablet computers, etc
word.entryExample: I can't increase the memory of my tablet as it doesn't have an SD card port.

word.entryDescription: a large area of open salty water
word.entryExample: I love swimming in the sea.

word.entryDescription: feeling ill because of the movement of a boat or ship that you are traveling on
word.entryExample: I worry about the children being sea sick on the boat if the weather is bad.

word.entryDescription: the part of a town facing the sea/ocean
word.entryExample: The sports centre is about five hundred metres from the seafront.

word.entryDescription: an official mark, or design stamped on a document to show that it is authentic
word.entryExample: Such seals with inscriptions were used in all their official documents.

word.entryDescription: a stone that was used to seal something during ancient times; engraved with some emblems
word.entryExample: The Indus script is found on many of the fascinating seal stones.

word.entryDescription: the skill in sailing a boat or ship that an experienced sailor has
word.entryExample: Athens grew rich on more than just trade, and her domination of the Aegean was due to more than just good seamanship.

word.entryDescription: a subculture with an identifiable style of music, design, and fashion
word.entryExample: Recent examples of internet subcultures include haul girls and seapunk.

word.entryDescription: to look for some information on the Internet
word.entryExample: Did you try searching the net?

word.entryDescription: the land at the edge of the sea or ocean, usually where there is sand and rocks
word.entryExample: Examples of habitats include desert, forest and seashore.

word.entryDescription: a place near the sea where people go for fun
word.entryExample: We went to the seaside at the wieekend.

word.entryDescription: happening during a particular season
word.entryExample: If more people bought local, seasonal food we’d avoid using up petrol, polluting the atmosphere and creating traffic jams with the lorries transporting it.

word.entryDescription: in the position of number two when we count
word.entryExample: Who was second in the race?

word.entryDescription: the second of the two halves of a game
word.entryExample: Williams scored a good second-half goal.

word.entryDescription: not new having been owned by someone else before
word.entryExample: He spends all his money buying second-hand DVDs and has over a thousand of them.

word.entryDescription: a school in the UK for children above the age of 11
word.entryExample: I'm at secondary school.

word.entryDescription: used for presenting a second argument
word.entryExample: Secondly, none of it is ever your fault.

word.entryDescription: plural of 'second' – a short unit of time; a sixtieth of a minute
word.entryExample: There are 60 seconds in a minute.

word.entryDescription: somebody who works in an office typing letters, making phone calls, arranging meetings, etc
word.entryExample: Is your sister a secretary?

word.entryDescription: to protect something from harm or damage
word.entryExample: Was your property secured against intruders?

word.entryDescription: protection against crime or attack, or the people who are responsible for this protection
word.entryExample: Don't bring anything with you apart from money and your phone because you can't get it through security.

word.entryDescription: to sense something with your eyes
word.entryExample: What kind of a film would you like to see this evening?

word.entryDescription: to see a performance for the public, especially one that includes singing, dancing, jokes; or to see a television or radio programme
word.entryExample: At Fun Land, you can see a show, take photos or go fishing.

word.entryDescription: a small object produced by a plant from which a new plant can grow
word.entryExample: You can buy seeds at the garden centre.

word.entryDescription: to appear to be
word.entryExample: Barry, who is our new graphic designer, seems to be very creative.

word.entryDescription: past participle form of 'see' – to sense something with your eyes
word.entryExample: Have you even seen a platypus?

word.entryDescription: very rarely
word.entryExample: I seldom teach yoga for children.

word.entryDescription: knowledge and understanding of yourself
word.entryExample: We think a fly lacks self-awareness. It does not know it's a fly.

word.entryDescription: only thinking of yourself; not caring about others
word.entryExample: She is popular, but she takes risks and doesn't care about others, so some people say she is irresponsible and selfish.
